question: BJCP Guidelines are a guidelines and should not be considered solely as a law during the judging process.
BJCP Guidelines are a strongly defined and should always be considered as a law during the judging process.
Cider is fermented apple juice. Perry is fermented pear juice
Cider is fermented pear juice. Perry is fermented apple juice
There are two categories for cider and perry: Standard Cider and Perry (Category C1) and Specialty Cider and Perry (Category C2)
There are three categories for cider and perry: Standard Cider and Perry (Category C1), Cider with Spice and other Fruits (C2), and Other Cider and Perry (Category C3)
The only adjunct permitted in the Standard category, is a limited addition of sugar to achieve a suitable starting gravity or to raise sweetness post-fermentation.

Different adjuncts permitted in the Standard category, are a addition of different sugars including honey, molasses and brown sugars to achieve a suitable starting gravity or to raise sweetness post-fermentation.
Ciders and perries do not necessarily present overtly fruity aromas or flavors — in the same sense that a wine does not taste overtly of grapes.
Ciders and perries must present rich fruity aromas or flavors of apples and pears — in the same sense that a wine does taste as  grapes.
Drier styles of cider develop more complex but less fruity characters.
Drier styles of cider must develop more complex, rich, fruity apple characters.
An apple soda or wine cooler character is not desirable in a cider or perry.
An apple soda or wine cooler character is a classic example of quality traditional cider or perry.
An apple soda or wine cooler character is not desirable in a cider or perry.
An apple soda or wine cooler character is a classic example of quality traditional cider or perry.
Some styles of cider exhibit distinctly non-fruity tastes or aromas, such as the smoky ham undertones of a dry English cider.
The sweetness (residual sugar, or RS) of a cider or perry may vary from absolutely dry (no RS) to as much as a sweet dessert wine (10% or more RS).
In sweeter ciders, other components of taste — particularly acidity — must balance the sweetness.
In dry ciders, other components of taste — particularly acidity — must balance the sweetness.
There are five categories of sweetness, expanded from three in earlier guidelines. Note that the numbers for these levels are not rigid or restrictive.
There are three categories of sweetness. Note that the numbers for these levels are restrictive.
Sweetness levels are intended to guide the cidermaker on how to enter ciders into competitions.
Sweetness levels are intended to be used as judging criteria specially if it is declared incorrectly.
Judges must realize that sweetness can mask faults. Judges must be  more attentive to this in a sweeter cider.
Judges must realize that sweetness can mask faults. Judges can be  more lenient on judging sweeter cider.
Judges should not penalize dry ciders excessively for minor faults which may be more evident only because of lack of sweetness.
Judges should penalize dry ciders for excessively minor faults because they are more evident because of lack of sweetness.
There are five sweetness levels in ciders: Dry, Medium-Dry, Medium, Medium-sweet, Sweet
There are five sweetness levels in ciders: Dry, Off-Dry, Medium, Sweet, Very Sweet
Which sweetness level is not one of the cider sweetness categories?
Acidity is an essential element of cider and perry: it must be sufficient to give a clean, refreshing impression without being puckering.
Acidity must not be confused with acetification (from ethyl acetate or acetic acid—vinegar)
The acrid aroma and tingling taste of acetification is a fault for standard ciders.
Ciders and perries vary considerably in tannin which affects both bitterness and astringency.
Ciders and perries vary considerably in tannin which do not affects both bitterness and astringency.
In ciders made from culinary or table fruit, tannins are typically low.
In ciders made from culinary or table fruit, tannins level are typically from low to high.
The character contributed by tannin should be mainly astringency rather than bitterness.
The character contributed by tannin should be mainly bitterness rather than astringency.
An overt or forward bitterness is a fault, and is often due to processing techniques rather than fruit character.
An overt or forward astringency is a fault, and is often due to processing techniques rather than fruit character.
Malo-lactic fermentation (MLF) process converts some or all of the sharp malic acid to softer, less-acidic lactic acid.
Malo-lactic fermentation (MLF) process converts some or all of the sharp tannins to softer, less-astringent tannins.
Perries generally should not go through MLF because it will cause undesirable acetification.
Perries should always go through MLF because it will smooth out undesirable acetification.
Dominating farmyard character may be the result of a Brettanomyces contamination rather than MLF.
Clarity may vary from good to brilliant. The lack of sparkling clarity is not a fault.
Clarity on ciders and perries must vary from good to brilliant. Lack of sparkling clarity is always a fault
Perries are notoriously difficult to clear; as a result a slight haze is not a fault.
Perries are difficult to clear, however a slight haze is always a fault
Carbonation in ciders and perries may vary from entirely still to a champagne level.
Carbonation in ciders and perries may vary from semi-carbonated to a champagne level
Usage of wood for Traditional Ciders and Perries (C1) is authorized but must be no more than barely recognizable.
Any of wood character in Traditional Ciders and Perries (C1) is not authorized is considered as serious fault.
Judges must not penalize still ciders (when declared properly) for lack of carbonation.
Judges may penalize still ciders (even when declared properly) for lack of carbonation but not by much.
Spanish cider does not yet have a style definition in BJCP guidelines, thus should be entered in the closest applicable category.
Spanish cider does not yet have a style definition in BJCP guidelines, but should be always entered in the New World Cider (C1A) category.
A New World Cider usually is made from culinary/table apples.
A New World Cider is made only from culinary/table apples.
Wild or crab apples are often used in A New World Cider for acidity/tannin balance.
Usage of wild or crab apples is prohibited in New World Cider. In this case cider must be entered as English Cider.
Compared to other traditional styles, New World Ciders are generally relatively lower in tannin and higher in acidity.
Compared to other traditional styles, New World Ciders are generally sweeter and contain more apple character.
New World Cider references the style, not a location, as ciders in this style are also made in eastern England, Australia, Germany, etc.
New World Cider references the location where the ciders are usually made, since traditional American apples are used for making it.
New World Cider are usually pale to medium gold in color.
New World Cider must be pale to medium gold in color. Any other colors including pick or red is a serious fault.
Some tannin should be present in New World Ciders for slight to moderate astringency, but little bitterness.
There should be no tannin present in New World Ciders nor any bitterness.
Sweet or low-alcohol New World ciders may have apple aroma and flavor.
Sweet or low-alcohol New World ciders should always have pronounced apple aroma and flavor.
It is okay for dry New World cider to lack an apple character but some esters are welcomed.
New World cider should not have any esters and/or must show an apple character in finished product.
English ciders are made with bittersweet and bitter-sharp apple varieties cultivated specifically for cider making.
English ciders are made with culinary and crab apple varieties cultivated specifically for cider making.
English ciders are traditionally fermented and aged in wood barrels, which adds some character.
English ciders are traditionally fermented in specialty barrels (Whiskey or Scotch) which adds additional layers of complexity.
Various flavors and esters in English Cider suggest apples, particularly tannic varieties.
Various noticable flavors and esters in English Cider suggest a fermentation issues and usually a flaw.
English-style ciders commonly go through Malo-lactic Fermentation (MLF).
Clean fermentation profile is desirable in English Ciders
English ciders may produces desirable spicy/smoky, phenolic, and farmyard/old-horse characters from MLF. These flavor notes are positive but not required.
English ciders may produces desirable spicy/smoky, phenolic, and farmyard/old-horse characters from MLF. These flavor are required and absence of which is a style flaw.
A strong farmyard character in English Cider without spicy/smoky or phenolic suggests a Brettanomyces contamination, which is a fault.
A strong farmyard character in English Cider comes from  Brettanomyces and does not have to cary spicy/smoky or phenolic characteristics.
English ciders can appear barely cloudy to brilliant.
English ciders should appear as clear to brillian.
English ciders can appear medium yellow to amber in color.
English ciders can appear yellow to gold in color.
Mousiness in English ciders is a serious fault.
Mousiness is not uncommon in English Ciders and traditional to some regional styles. Usually not a flaw.
English Ciders have moderate to high tannin, perceived as astringency and some bitterness.
English Ciders have low to moderate tannin, softened by sweetness and rarely bitter.
English Ciders are usually carbonated from still to moderate level.
English Ciders are should be still. Any carbonation is a stylistic flaw.
Bottle-fermented or -conditioned English ciders may have high carbonation, up to champagne levels, but not gushing or foaming.
Bottle-fermented or -conditioned English ciders may have high carbonation, but never up to champagne levels.
Sweet examples of English ciders do exist, but dry is most traditional, particularly when considering the drying contributions of tannin.
English ciders are never sweet, particularly when considering the drying contributions of tannin.
French Cider includes Normandy styles plus ciders inspired by those styles.
French Cider includes "West County", styles plus ciders inspired by those styles.
French Ciders traditionally are made with bittersweet and bitter-sharp apple varieties cultivated specifically for cider making.
French Ciders traditionally are made with sweet and sharp apple varieties cultivated specifically for culinary purposes.
Traditional French procedures use small amounts of salt and calcium compounds (calcium chloride, calcium carbonate) to aid the process of pectin coagulation in French Ciders.
Traditional French procedures use small amounts of salt and calcium compounds (potassium chloride, calcium nitrate) to aid the process of proteins breakup in French apples.
Slow or arrested fermentation can be used as part of a French technique of Défécation.
Défécation is a French technique of introducing wild bacteria into a cider for developing a MLF.
MLF notes of spicy-smoky, phenolic, and farmyard in French ciders are common but not required, and must not be pronounced.
MLF notes of spicy-smoky, phenolic, and farmyard in sweet French ciders are required.
The French expect more subtle MLF character than do the English.
The French expect more sharp MLF character than do the English
French ciders have moderate tannin, perceived mainly as astringency.
French ciders have high tannin, perceived mainly as bitterness but balanced out with sweetness.
French ciders typically made sweet to balance the tannin levels from the traditional apple varieties.
French ciders typically made dry to semi-dry to let the tannin levels from the traditional apple varieties shine.
Rosé Cider is intended for any Standard Cider whose pink color is derived entirely from red-fleshed and/or red-skinned apples.
Rosé Cider is intended for any Specialty Cider whose pink color is derived additions of red berries like cranberries, raspberries, strawberries, etc.
A Rosé Cider often has aromas and flavors associated with strawberries, raspberries, cranberries, or other red-fleshed fruits such as watermelon.
A Rosé Cider often has aromas and flavors associated with dark fruit, raisins, plums, prunes, or other dried stone fruits.
The intensity of the pink color in Rosé Ciders will vary depending on the varieties used and the production techniques.
The intensity of the pink color in Rosé Ciders will vary depending on the amount of fruit adjuncts (raspberries, strawberries) used and the production techniques.

Natural (or Spanish) Cider is intended for ciders from Asturias, the Basque Country, and other regions in which similar apple varieties and production techniques are used to achieve a typical Spanish cider profile.
Traditional Spanish cider is made primarily with sharp and semi-sharp traditional apple varieties.
Traditional Spanish cider is made primarily with bitter-sweet traditional apple varieties.
Spanish cider tradition allow wild yeasts to ferment the cider, rather than using cultured yeasts.
Spanish cider are commonly fermented with champagne yeast in order to avoid wild yeast contamination.
Traditional Spanish cider requires both alcoholic and malolactic fermentation (MLF) to reach completeness.
Traditional Spanish cider are rarely undergo through malolactic fermentation (MLF) in order to preserve complexity.
Escanciar is the traditional technique of pouring the Spanish cider by raising the bottle above their head and the cider cascades from the bottle into the glass which he is holding below.
Espichar is the traditional technique of pouring the Spanish cider by raising the bottle above their head and the cider cascades from the bottle into the glass which he is holding below.
Espichar is the traditional technique of pouring the Spanish cider directly from a barrel or tank to the glass which is held at an angle.
Escanciar is the traditional technique of pouring the Spanish cider directly from a barrel or tank to the glass which is held at an angle.
Only a small amount of Spanish cider is poured into a glass, just enough to consume in a mouthful or two.
Usually a full glass of Spanish cider is poured into a glass, this should be enough to overcompensate for the lack of carbonation.
Spanish ciders are poured into a glass from the height in order to release carbon dioxide in the cider and to volatilize part of the acetic acid.
Spanish ciders are usually poured into a glass with caution in order to prevent the release of carbon dioxide in the cider and volatilizing of the acetic acid.
Depending on the region Spanish Ciders typically have fresh citric and floral aromas and/or light spice, leather, and smoke aroma.
Depending on the region Spanish Ciders typically have fresh tropical, estery, fruity aromas and flavor.
Aged cheese and butter aromas may be encountered in Spanish Ciders, but any excess is undesirable.
Aged cheese and butter aromas in ciders are always undesirable and a big flaw disregarding the style.
Spanish ciders are unfiltered, so cloudiness is normal.
Spanish ciders are well filtered unfiltered, so cloudiness and haziness is a flaw.
The color for Spanish ciders should be straw yellow to deep gold.
Due to special apples, the color for Spanish ciders should be deep gold to light brown.
Carbonation in Spanish ciders is light to moderate, depending on the height of the pour.
Carbonation in Spanish ciders is moderate to high, depending on amount of priming sugar used.
Taste profile of Spanish Cider is acidic/tangy, citric/lemony, with little to no astringency or bitterness.
Taste profile of Spanish Cider is sweet, appley caramel, with medium-low to high astringency or bitterness
Pleasant scratchy and tickly throat due to acetic acid in Spanish Cider is expected (often more intense in Basque ciders)
Scratchy and tickly throat due to acetic acid in Spanish Cider is a flaw (specially in Basque ciders)
Foam (Espalme) in Spanish Ciders must disappear quickly from the top of the cider.
Foam (Espalme) in Spanish Ciders is sticky and should be medium and lasting.
New World Perry is a perry made from culinary/table pears.
New World Perry is a perry made from "New World" types of pears grown in mostly in North America.
Very slight acetification for New World perries is acceptable.
New world perry should show clean fermentation profile with No acetification of any kind.
Mousiness, ropy/oily characters in New World perries are serious faults..
Mousiness, ropy/oily characters in New World perries is acceptable in smaller qualities due to the nature of the fruit.
New World perries are slightly cloudy to clear.
New World perries are clear to brilliant clear
Perries provide relatively full mouthfeel, with low to moderate tannin apparent as astringency.
Perries provide relatively full mouthfeel, with low to none tannin level. No astringency.
New World perries have a pear character, but not obviously fruity
New World perries must have pronounced pear character, with obvious fruitiness from medium high to high
Some pears may contain significant amounts of natural sweetener sorbitol.
Some pears may contain significant amounts of natural sweeteners like erythritolh and xylitol.
Due to presence of sorbitol in some pears, dry perry may give an impression of sweetness.
Due to presence of sorbitol in some pears, dry perry may give an impression of bitterness and astringency.
Entrants should specify sweetness of perries according to actual residual sugar amount, and judges must be aware that they might perceive more sweetness than how the perry was entered.
Entrants should specify sweetness of perries according to how the sweetness is perceived and not to actual gravity readings.
Traditional perry is made from pears grown specifically for that purpose rather than for eating or cooking.
Traditional perry is made with traditional techniques using natural fermentation process and natural carbonation.
Unlike New World, Traditional Perry is more tannic.
New World and Traditional Perries have fairly equal amount of tannins.
Only very slight acetification is acceptable for Traditional Perries.
No acetification is acceptable for Traditional Perries since it must show clean fermentation profile.
Unlike New World, Traditional Perry has more bitterness.
Unlike New World, Traditional Perry has fairly the same amount of bitterness.
Traditional perries are relatively full in mouthfeel with moderate to high tannin apparent as astringency.
Traditional perries are relatively medium to full in mouthfeel with moderate low to medium high tannin apparent as astringency.
New England Cider is a cider made with characteristic New England apples for relatively high acidity, with additives to raise alcohol levels and contribute additional flavor notes.
New England Cider is a hazy fruity, juice cider with no astringency or bitterness.
New England Cider adjuncts may include white and brown sugars, molasses, small amounts of honey, etc.
New England Cider must be adjuncts only with brown sugars or neutral (clover) honey.
New England Cider is sometimes barrel-aged, in which case there will be oak character as with a barrel-aged wine.
New England Cider is sometimes barrel-aged, but any oak character should be low to now and only used for extra tannins.
It is acceptable to use specialty barrels (whisky, rum, etc) for New England Cider, in which case some flavor notes from the spirit may also be present, but must be subtle.
Specialty spirit barrels (whisky, rum, etc) should not be used for New England Cider, since strong character may disturb the specialty sugar characteristics.
It is acceptable to use specialty barrels (whisky, rum, etc) for New England Cider, in which case some flavor notes from the spirit may also be present, but must be subtle.
Specialty spirit barrels (whisky, rum, etc) should not be used for New England Cider, since strong character may disturb the specialty sugar characteristics.
The Beverage made from both apples and pear juice should be entered into Cider with Other Fruit (C2B) category.
The Beverage made from both apples and pear juice can be entered either as a New World Cider (C1A) or New World Perry (C1D) depending on proportions of the juice in the blend.
In Cider with Other Fruit, the apple character must marry with the added fruit so that neither one dominates the other
In Cider with Other Fruit (C2B), it is a fault if the added fruit(s) completely dominate the palette.
In Cider with Other Fruit (C2B), it is okay if the added fruit(s) completely dominate the palette.
In Cider with Other Fruit (C2B), it is a fault if the added fruit(s) completely dominate the palette.
In Cider with Other Fruit (C2B), it is okay if the added fruit(s) completely dominate the palette.
Cider with Other Fruit (C2B), may be significantly tannic, depending on fruit added.
Cider with Other Fruit (C2B), never should be tannic.
Applewine (C2C) is simply a cider with substantial added sugar to achieve higher alcohol than a standard cider.
Applewine (C2C) is simply a cider blended with a white (rarely red) wine to achieve higher alcohol than a standard cider.
No fruit other than apples may be used in Applewine (C2C).
Smaller quantities of neutral white wine may be used in production of Applewine (C2C).
Applewine is typically like a dry white wine, balanced, and with low astringency and bitterness.
Applewine is typically like a red wine, balanced, and with high fruitiness and medium tannins.
Cloudiness or hazes are inappropriate in Applewine (C2C).
Younger versions of Applewine (C2C) may show some light cloudiness or haze.
Applewine (C2C) is lighter than other ciders, because higher alcohol is derived from addition of sugar rather than juice.
Applewine (C2C) is more full and richer than other ciders, because of additional sugar additions.
This is a cider style in which the juice is concentrated before fermentation either by freezing fruit before pressing or freezing juice and removing water.
This is a cider style in which the regular cider is concentrated by freezing removing water after fermentation is done.
During the production of Ice Cider fermentation stops or is arrested before reaching dryness.
During the production of Ice Cider fermentation process does need to stop and can go as low as 5˚brix.
The character of Ice Cider differs from Applewine in that the itsice cider process increases not only sugar (hence alcohol) but acidity and all fruit flavor components proportionately.
The character of Ice Cider is similar to Applewine in that the ice cider process increases sugar and alcohol components proportionately.
No additives are permitted in Ice Cider (C2D) style; in particular, sweeteners may not be used to increase gravity.
It is not uncommon to use additives in Ice Cider (C2D) style; in particular, maple syrup and other sweeteners may be used to increase gravity or for back-sweetening.
Ice Cider style originated in Quebec, Canada in the 1990s.
Ice Cider (also known Cidre de Glace) style originated in Normandy region of France at the end of the 19th century.
Ice Cider style originated in Quebec, Canada in the 1990s.
Ice Cider (also known Cidre de Glace) style originated in Normandy region of France at the end of the 19th century.
Finishing gravity of an Ice Cider (C2D) can be fairly high, up to 20.5˚Brix or 1.085
Finishing gravity of an Ice Cider (C2D) can be fairly high, up to 15˚Brix or 1.060
Starting gravity of an Ice Cider (C2D) can be fairly high, up to 40˚Brix or 1.180
Starting gravity of an Ice Cider (C2D) can be fairly high, up to 24˚Brix or 1.100
Finishing gravity of an Ice Cider (C2D) can be fairly high, starting at 15˚Brix or 1.060
Finishing gravity of traditional examples of Ice Cider (C2D) can be low as 5˚Brix or 1.020
Cider with Herbs/Spices (C2E) should include hopped ciders since hops are considered as a herb.
Hopped Ciders must be entered into Specialty Cider/Perry (C2F) category due to the experimental nature of the cider
In Cider with Herbs/Spices the apple character must marry with the botanicals and give a balanced result.
In Specialty Cider/Perry the apple character must marry with the botanicals and give a balanced result.
Oxidation in Cider with Herbs/Spices of either the base cider or the additions is a fault.
Oxidation in Cider with Herbs/Spices of either the base cider or the additions is a desired as it adds layers and complexity.
