Gravenstein is among the most well-known early season apples and has enough acidity and sugar to make a single-varietal cider.
Gravenstein is among the most well-known early season apples and has very high acidity thus are not suitable for a single-varietal cider.
Gravenstein is among the most well-known early season apples and has very high acidity thus for making a good balanced cider they must be balanced with much sweeter variety.
Early apples tend to be good at balancing an extremely high acid/sugar blend while providing complexity to the aroma.
Early apples tend to be imbalanced due to a high acid blend content while providing single dimensional aroma.
Acid levels in crabapples can vary from moderately to extremely high; however, many crabs also have high sugar levels.
Acid levels in crabapples can vary from moderately to extremely high; however, most of crabs have low sugar levels, thus always must be blended with sweeter apples.
Balance in cider/perry refers to the interaction and harmony between two or more of the cider’s constituents.
Coupage in cider/perry refers to the interaction and harmony between two or more of the cider’s constituents.
Like mead and beer, cider is not a homogenous product.
Unlike mead and beer, cider is a homogenous product.
Cider balance is the synergy of all the components that formulate an enjoyable tasting experience: aroma, flavor, structure, residual sweetness, and mouthfeel.
Cider balance is the synergy of all the components in equal proportions: sweetness, acid, tannins, and alcohol level.
Balanced does not mean levels of multiple components are equal, but rather complement each other in a harmonious manner.
Balance in quality cider means levels of multiple components are equal and none of them is dominant.
Individual components may slightly overshadow one another, and the resulting combination is appropriate for the particular style of cider.
Individual components must not overshadow one another, and the resulting is appropriate balance for of cider.
What is in balance for one style of Cider/Perry may be well out of balance for another.
Determining balance in ciders is somewhat arbitrary – it may differ dramatically depending on the subjectivity of the taster, the cider style, apples or pears native to the area, or traditional bias.

Determining balance in ciders should not be arbitrary and must not differ dramatically depending on the cider style, apples or pears native to the area, or traditional bias. It should be based on BJCP guidelines.
A cider maker may consider balance up front with the choice of ingredients, after fermentation in terms of adjustment or blending, or a combination of both.
The more attention given to balance cider up the front the less adjustment and blending will generally be necessary at the finish.
Balance up the front plays little to no role in cider since adjustments and blending post fermentation still will be required.
There is no accurate formula for calculating a perfect acid-sugar-tannin balance in cider.
There is a formula for calculating a perfect acid-sugar-tannin balance in cider that is mostly used by English cidermakers.
There is no accurate formula for calculating a perfect acid-sugar-tannin balance in cider.
Cidermakers use a formula for calculating a perfect acid-sugar-tannin balance in cider that that was created by English cidermakers.
The flavors from apples, pears, or added ingredients (fruit, spice, etc.) should also be considered in determining the balance.
The flavors from apples, pears, or added ingredients (fruit, spice, etc.) are rarely considered in determining the balance because it is different from style to style.
Sweet ciders are obviously sweeter, so they need more structure (acidity, tannin, alcohol) to support them than do dry ciders.
Sweet ciders are obviously sweeter, thus they need less structure (acidity, tannin, alcohol) to support them than do dry ciders.
Which of the following is not considered as one of the components of balance?
Acidity is the perception of acids or low pH in cider, and sometimes could be described as tartness or sourness.
Tannins is the perception of acids or low pH in cider, and sometimes could be described as bitterness or astringency.
Acidity can be a primary flavor in a cider.
Acidity should never be a primary flavor in a cider.
Acidity is a vital component of cider and perry.
After the apple/pear character, acidity is a second vital component of cider and perry.
Acidity effect on mouthfeel can be to cut through the viscosity provided by residual sweetness.
Acidity effect on mouthfeel can cut through the viscosity provided by residual sweetness, bringing cider out of balance, thus rarely desired.
Cider with high acidity will generally age better than that with low.
Cider with high acidity will generally does not age well as ciders with low acidity, since it has a chance of turning it into a vinegar.
Malic acid is the predominant acid found in apples, often representing more than 95% of the acidity in this fruit.
Tartaric acid is the predominant acid found in apples, often representing more than 95% of the acidity in this fruit.
The flavor and character of malic acid is strongly associated with apples.
The flavor and character of tartaric acid is strongly associated with apples.
Unripe fruits tend to be full of malic acid – that which can provide freshness in a moderate amount.
Ripe fruits tend to be full of malic acid – that which can provide freshness at high level.
Malic acid is odorless with a sharp, strong taste of green apples or rhubarb and can be harsh and metallic at high levels.
Malic acid is flavorless with a sharp, strong aroma of green apples or rhubarb and can be harsh and metallic at high levels.
Citric acid is quite common in pears and in some pear cultivars is the predominant acid instead of malic.
Citric acid is quite common in apples and in some apple cultivars is the predominant acid instead of malic.
Citric acid is weaker than malic and a target for multiple microorganisms during fermentation.
Citric acid is stronger than malic and acts like a shield for multiple microorganisms during fermentation.
Which acid is odorless with a fairly-distinctive tangy/sour flavor, associated more with a “freshness” character than the “green apple” character?
Which acid is odorless with a sharp, strong taste of green apples or rhubarb and can be harsh and metallic at high levels?
Which acid has the distinctive smell and flavor of vinegar, along with a harshness in the swallow and burning sensation in the back of throat?
Which acid is predominant only in grapes? Other fruits containing much smaller amounts of this acid include tamarind, apricot, some cranberries, and prickly pears.
Not generally used to promote stability, ascorbic acid’s primary purpose in cider is as an antioxidant, typically for stability of color in juice or a finished beverage.
Generally used to promote stability, ascorbic acid’s secondary purpose in cider is as an antibacterial protection.
Lactic acid is weaker than malic, and reduction of malic into lactic by lactic acid bacteria (LAB) during MLF will reduce acidity and increase pH of the cider.
Lactic acid is softer than malic, and reduction of malic into lactic by lactic acid bacteria (LAB) during MLF will increase acidity and reduce pH of the cider yet making the cider smoother.
Lactic acid is weaker than malic, and reduction of malic into lactic by lactic acid bacteria (LAB) during MLF will reduce acidity and increase pH of the cider.
Lactic acid is softer than malic, and reduction of malic into lactic by lactic acid bacteria (LAB) during MLF will increase acidity and reduce pH of the cider yet making the cider smoother.
Acetic acid is usually considered a positive flavor and aroma contributor at very low – not discernable – levels.
Acetic acid is usually considered a negative flavor and aroma contributor at any level and always a flaw.
As soon as it is noticeable acetic acid is generally a fault, with the exception of Perry where very low amounts are allowable.
As soon as it is noticeable acetic acid is always a fault, across all the styles or fruit types.
Acetic Acid is part of Volatile Acidity (VA), and permissible in Spanish style ciders (often more intense in Basque ciders).
Acetic Acid is part of Volatile Acidity (VA), and is always considered as a big flaw at any level or intensity.
Tartaric is a target of significantly fewer microbes than malic or citric, tending to make it more stable than the other two.
Tartaric is a target of significantly more microbes than malic or citric, tending to make it more unstable than the other two.
Tartaric is a target of significantly fewer microbes than malic or citric, tending to make it more stable than the other two.
Tartaric is a target of significantly more microbes than malic or citric, tending to make it more unstable than the other two.
Fruitiness and sugar levels can vary significantly by cultivar, region, weather, soil, and year.
Fruitiness and sugar levels usually do not significantly vary by cultivar, region, weather, soil, and year.
Adding sugar sources to cider can restart fermentation if the cider has not been stabilized first.
Adding sugar sources to cider should not restart fermentation even if the cider has been stabilized first.
Dry ciders can still have some body, usually with the increased structure coming from acidity or tannin.
In dry ciders increased structure coming from acidity or tannin has no effect on a body of a cider.
Cider judges should not expect cider to taste like common store bought dessert apples any more than they expect wine to taste like table grapes.
Cider judges should expect cider to taste like common apples because it is a part of the balance. Lack of apple character is a serious flaw.
The commonly heard “not appley enough” comments from inexperienced judges are not appropriate critique or feedback for most styles.
If a dry cider shows lack of apple aroma or flavor it is okay to comment “not appley enough” in a feedback.
Higher alcohol ciders can generally support higher residual sugar levels in the finished product.
Higher alcohol ciders generally do support higher residual sugar levels in the finished product since it bring the cider out of balance.
In apples and pears tannins are a group of several bitter and astringent plant polyphenols called procyanidins.
In apples and pears tannins are a group of several bitter and astringent plant polyphenols called sorbitol.
Large molecules of polyphenols (tannins) are not volatile, hence they have no aroma.
Small molecules of polyphenols (tannins) are volatile, hence they have sharp noticeable aroma.
Larger procyanidins tend to be astringent, giving a puckering mouthfeel and drying sensation, and are sometimes called “soft” tannins.
Larger procyanidins tend to be astringent, giving a tickling mouthfeel and sour sensation, and are sometimes called “bittersharp” tannins.
Over time tannins tend to polymerize, increasing in size, bitterness smoothing into astringency, thus a cider that is a too bitter may improve with age.
Over time tannins tend to polymerize, increasing in size, light astringency turning into bitternes, thus a cider that has some astringency may worsen with age.
Most mass-produced, well known apples and pears are quite low in tannin, especially dessert fruits.
Most mass-produced, well known apples and pears are quite rich in tannin, especially table fruits.
Though tannins themselves have no aroma, they can reduce aroma by binding with esters and alcohol or add new aromas from the tannin source (fruits, wood, spices).
Since tannins themselves have no aroma, they do not have any effect on aroma in a finished product.
Generally higher alcohol beverages can support more tannin as long as the acidity is not also high, at which point the beverage becomes harsh and hard to drink.
Generally higher alcohol beverages can support more tannin as long as the acidity is also high, at which point the beverage becomes more balanced and easy to drink.
Tannins perform some antiseptic functions, helping to protect cider against certain bacteria, and also generally serve an antioxidant role in preservation.
Unlike sulfites and acid, tannins do not have any antiseptic functions, and also generally increase a chance of oxidation.
The drying sensation on the palate in red wines, sometimes called “puckering” but not to be confused with the somewhat similar “puckeringly sour” acidic character.
The drying sensation on the palate in red wines, sometimes called “puckering” is the same “puckeringly sour” acidic character.
Astringency increases body by literally giving more tactile sensation.
Astringency increases body by literally increasing viscosity and density of a cider.
Astringency can lengthen the finish of the cider by lasting into the swallow and aftertaste.
Astringency can shorten the finish of the cider even after lasting into the swallow and aftertaste.
Usually "dry" indicates a lack of residual sugar, however in cider (or mead / wine), "dry" can also mean a considerable tannin content.
Usually "dry" indicates a lack of residual sugar, however in cider (or mead / wine), "dry" can also mean a considerable acid content or small body.
Judges should try to make clear which they are talking about – the lack of residual sugar indicating a dry cider, or the drying effect of tannins.
From cider judging point of view there is no need in clarifying what judges mean about "dryness" – the lack of residual sugar indicating a dry cider, or the drying effect of tannins.
Cider bitterness can range from very low in most styles, to a moderate part of the balance in some English ciders.
Cider bitterness can range from very low in most styles, to a high part of the balance in some American (specially West Coast) ciders.
Higher alcohol will emphasize bitterness, as will lack of sweetness, higher acidity, colder serving temperature, or higher carbonation.
Lower alcohol level will emphasize bitterness, as will low acidity, warmer serving temperature, or low carbonation.
Barely perceivable bitterness isn’t a major flaw in ciders.
Even barely perceivable bitterness is a major flaw in ciders.
In BJCP cider styles bitterness should not be a major component of balance in the manner of many hop-forward beers.
In some BJCP cider styles bitterness can be a major component of balance only if it is in the manner of hop-forward beers.
Besides apple or pear tannins, sources of bitterness may include spices or oxidation.
Sources of bitterness in ciders usually comes only from apple or pear tannins.
Though the interplay of acidity and sugar is the biggest component of the balance of most cider, they do not usually provide enough structure on their own for a fully balanced cider.
Interplay of acidity and sugar is the biggest component of the balance of most cider, which usually provides enough structure on their own for a fully balanced cider.
Attempting to balance a cider with both high levels of sugar and acidity without regard to other components can give a “sweet-tart” impression.
Attempting to balance a cider with both high levels of sugar and acidity without regard to other components can give a “bitter-sharp” impression.
Alcohol adds some structure to all cider, though for some of the sweeter, low-alcohol French style ciders, said structure is negligible.
Alcohol adds some structure to all cider, including for some of the French style ciders, said structure should not be negligible.
Judges should expect alcohol to be a major component of the balance in Applewine, often so in New England Cider and Ice Cider.
Alcohol should never be a major component of the balance in Applewine, often so in New England Cider and Ice Cider, since it can throw the balance off in listed styles.
Ethanol also has a sharp flavor and can add bitterness while also being perceived by some people as sweet.
Ethanol also has a soft flavor and can reduce bitterness while also being perceived by some people as tart.
Though cider has more in common with wine than beer, the alcohol levels in the majority of ciders you will encounter in competition are more akin to beer than wine.
Just like cider has more in common with wine than beer, the alcohol levels in the majority of ciders you will encounter in competition are more akin to wine than beer.
Dry cider should have almost no residual sugar, and thus little to cover alcohol.
Dry cider still should have some residual sugar to cover the alcohol.
Alcohol may be detectable at a lower level in dry cider than in a beer with the same alcohol but higher residual sweetness and final gravity.
Alcohol should not be detectable at any level in dry cider since it brings the cider out of balance.
A cider with high alcohol will likely have a sharper aroma profile, a drier finish, more residual warmth on the palate, and greater perceived bitterness than that of a low alcohol example.

A cider with high alcohol will likely have a smoother aroma profile, a warmer finish, more residual sweetness (from ethanol) on the palate, and lower perceived bitterness than that of a low alcohol example.
A cider with lower alcohol will more likely allow the natural apple or pear aroma and flavor along with, acidity, and tannin to come through.
A cider with lower alcohol will more likely mute the natural apple or pear aroma and flavor along with, acidity, and tannin to be subdued.
Higher alcohol content can help a sweeter cider avoid a raw or unfermented impression.
Higher alcohol content can help a dryer cider avoid a raw or wild impression.
Stopping fermentation of ciders before it completes (intentionally or unintentionally) results in lower alcohol.
Stopping fermentation of ciders before it completes (intentionally or unintentionally) results in sharper "hotter" alcohol.
Body refers to the viscosity of cider perceived as a sensation of weight or thickness on the tongue.
Mouthfeel refers to the viscosity of cider perceived as a sensation of weight or thickness on the tongue.
Body of a cider/perry is a mouthfeel texture, not a flavor.
Body of a cider/perry is a flavor texture, not a mouthfeel.
Thin and watery are terms that describe very light-bodied ciders.
Thin and watery are terms that describe dry New World ciders.
Cloying, viscous, heavy, thick are terms that describe very full-bodied ciders.
Cloying, viscous, heavy, thick are terms that describe French ciders.
Managing cider fermentation for final gravity can thus control the final body.
Managing cider fermentation for final gravity can has little control the final body since most of the sugars in the cider are highly fermentable.
Back-sweetening cider can increase body.
Back-sweetening cider does not usually increase body since it leads to restarting the fermentation.
Using more juice (fermented or not), honey, molasses, brown sugar, and some fruits generally increases body.
Using more juice (fermented or not), honey, molasses, brown sugar, and some fruits usually does not increase body but may change the cider's category.
Higher alcohol content and tannin levels increase body by offering greater tactile sensation.
Higher alcohol content and tannin levels usually decrease the body since alcohol is much lighter by volume then water or juice.
Carbonation refers to the amount of dissolved carbon dioxide in solution.
Carbonation refers to the amount of dissolved hydrogen dioxide in solution.
Carbonation is an aspect of mouthfeel, although higher carbonation adds carbonic acid to cider.
Carbonation is an aspect of a flavor since carbonation adds carbonic acid to cider.
Carbonic acid is a very weak acid, but does increase perceived acidity and reduce pH.
Carbonic acid is a very strong acid and it does increase acidity and reduce pH, thus must be used with caution.
Carbonation also can cut through high sweetness levels in cider that would otherwise be cloying.
Carbonation also can cut through high tannins levels in cider that would otherwise be bitter.
Carbonation increase perceived bitterness or astringency.
Carbonation increase perceived sweetness or cloyingness by activating more sensors at the base of the tongue.
High amounts of carbonation can greatly amplify attributes in a cider, particularly the aroma profile.
High amounts of carbonation can greatly overshadow attributes in a cider, particularly the aroma profile.
Still ciders do not have to be totally flat; they can have some very light bubbles.
Still ciders should not have any carbonation; ciders with some very light bubbles must be classified as petillant.
Petillant ciders are “lightly sparkling” and can have a moderate, noticeable amount of carbonation.
Petillant ciders are “well carbonated” and can have a moderate to high amount of bubbling.
The fermentation process can influence acidity (pH drops during fermentation), with some yeast impacting more than others.
The fermentation process can influence astringency (chlorophenols amount increase during fermentation), with some yeast impacting more than others.
The fermentation process can influence acidity (pH drops during fermentation), with some yeast impacting more than others.
The fermentation process can influence astringency (chlorophenols amount increase during fermentation), with some yeast impacting more than others.
Cider makers will frequently adjust the acidity level of their cider usually post-fermentation.
Cider makers rarely or never adjust the acidity level of their cider since it might throw cider out of balance and usually against traditional methods.
The sweetness-acidity-tannin balance is most important in determining the overall drinkability of cider.
The sweetness-acidity-tannin balance is most important in determining the amount of three components of cider in equal proportions .
The balance between cider flavors and those of added fruit or spices is important in New England, fruit, and herb/spiced ciders.
The balance between cider flavors and those of added fruit or spices is important in New England, fruit, and herb/spiced ciders as long as the apple character is dominant and well pronounced.
Low apple/pear character and acidity together will make a cider seem boring.
Low apple/pear character and acidity together is okay for some styles as long as it is balanced out with lower ABV.
A cider with low sweetness compared to acidity will seem tart or sour.
A cider with low sweetness compared to acidity will seem imbalanced and always should be considered as flawed.
A cider with high sweetness compared to acidity will seem flabby and soft.
A cider with high sweetness compared to acidity will seem more balanced then a cider with low sweetness compared to acidity.
The combined tannin and acidity must roughly match the amount of alcohol to be in balance.
The combined tannin and acidity must precisely match the amount of alcohol to be in balance.
Higher carbonation can also balance higher body, making the cider seem lighter.
Higher carbonation can throw the cider out of balance, making the cider seem heavier by increasing the mouthfeel.
Higher carbonation can also balance higher body, making the cider seem lighter.
Higher carbonation can throw the cider out of balance, making the cider seem heavier by increasing the mouthfeel.
While it may seem like tannin and acidity can be interchanged, acidity doesn't make a cider/perry seem dry.
While it may seem like tannin and acidity can be interchanged, acidity does make a cider/perry seem more dry.
Too little alcohol will cause the acidity and astringency to dominate, making the cider harsh and thin.
Too much alcohol will cause the acidity and astringency to dominate over sweetness, making the cider harsh and thin.
Too little acid and astringency will cause the cider to taste overly soft, heavy and flabby, with the spirity quality of the alcohol playing too much of a role.
Too little acid and astringency will cause the cider to taste overly fresh, juicy and appley, making it more desirable and easy drinking for traditional ciders.
A considerable amount of tannin is more acceptable if acidity is low and alcohol is high.
A considerable amount of tannin is more acceptable for the balance if acidity is high and alcohol is low.
Cider tolerates acidity better when the alcohol content is higher.
Cider tolerates acidity better when the alcohol content is lower.
In mead and cider, low serving temperatures make tannins seem much more apparent while suppressing the relevant honey/apple/pear characters.
In mead and cider, higher serving temperatures (above 65˚F) make tannins seem much more apparent while suppressing the relevant honey/apple/pear characters.
In some instances balance in cider/perry can be achieved simply by manipulating serving temperature.
Acetaldehyde usually appears in aroma and flavor as of green apple, green apple candy, freshly cut grass, green leaves, or occasionally latex paint.
Solvent usually appears in aroma and flavor as of green apple, green apple candy, freshly cut grass, green leaves, or occasionally latex paint.
At very high levels acetaldehyde may remind of banana or rotting citrus, at which point it indicates a serious problem.
At very high levels acetaldehyde may remind of cucumbers or rotting tomatoes, at which point it indicates a serious problem.
Acetaldehyde typically formed during normal fermentation but cleaned up later in the process.
Acetaldehyde typically formed during malo-lactic fermentation and but cleaned up later by long aging.
Very high levels of acetaldehyde may be indicative of Cider Sickness, caused by Zymomonas bacteria.
Very high levels of sulfur dioxide may be indicative of Cider Sickness, caused by Zymomonas bacteria.
Acetic Acid appears as sharp, harsh sourness, with vinegary aroma and flavor. Often gives a burning feeling in the back of the throat when swallowed.
Solvent Acid appears as sharp, harsh sourness, with vinegary aroma and flavor. Often gives a burning feeling in the back of the throat when swallowed.
Acetic Acid is inappropriate at any level at any cider or perry style.
Acetic Acid is accepted in very low amounts in perries.
Acetic Acid is accepted in higher amounts in Spanish and other sour ciders or perries.
Acetic is often considered a flavor positive at very low levels.
Acetic acid is formed by Acetobacter, film yeast or Brettanomyces infection in the presence of oxygen.
Hydrogen Sulfide (rotten eggs) is formed by Acetobacter, film yeast or Brettanomyces infection in the presence of oxygen.
Perry can sometimes naturally have a very light degree of acetification which is unrelated to contamination.
Perry can usually naturally have a very light degree of acetification which due to improper or poor controls during fermentation.
Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria characterized by large amounts of the flavor and aroma of acetaldehyde, presenting as rotten lemon or banana peel.
Mousey in cider characterized by large amounts of the flavor and aroma of acetaldehyde, presenting as rotten lemon or banana peel.
Cider infected with Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria infection is often extremely hazy, even turbid, and almost milky in appearance.
Cider infected with Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria infection is often expresses shiny surface texture with unpleasant slimy character in mouthfeel..
Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria infection can be avoided with elevated acid and fermentation that proceeds completely to dryness.
Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria infection can be avoided with addition of pectic enzymes and finishing with malo-lactic fermentation.
Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria infection is fairly uncommon in North American homemade cider.
Cider Sickness or Zymomonas bacteria infection is very common in North American homemade cider from apples that are manually pressed.
Temperatures below 50F and lowering pH by addition of malic acid can retard further growth of Zymomonas bacteria.
Pasteurization Temperatures above 75˚F and increasing pH by addition of potassium-carbonate can retard further growth of Zymomonas bacteria.
Zymomonas bacteria, also known “Framboise” bacteria in France is a spoilage bacteria and must be control in any cider.
Zymomonas bacteria, also known “Framboise” bacteria in France is used for Malo-lactic fermentation in French and some English ciders.
Perry is notoriously difficult to clear and thus some haze is not a fault.
Perry is notoriously difficult to clear and thus some haze is not a fault.
Since Spanish ciders are unfiltered and shaking the bottle before opening and pouring is recommended, cloudiness in this case is normal.
Cloudiness and haze is inappropriate for all styles, since it can affect the final score and impression negatively.
Cidermakers may add pectic enzyme to juice before fermentation begins to reduce the pectic haze in the cider.
Cidermakers may add diastatic enzyme to juice before fermentation begins to reduce the protein haze in the cider.
A one-note flavor may seem cloying at a lower sweetness than a complex flavor.
Disregarding the type of cider, anything above 15˚Brix (1.060) is considered to be cloying and a fault.
Judges should expect some variation in opinion at the judging table as to where “sweetness” ends and where “cloyingness” begins.
Judges should keep in mind, that “sweet” level usually begins at 1.020 and ends at 1.060, and anything above 1.060 falls into “cloying” category.
To prevent cider from being cloying cidermaker may do post-fermentation adjustment or blending. Cloying cider is difficult to fix once in the bottle.
Cloying cider is difficult to fix once in the bottle. It must be stored at the room temperature with medium humidity to let complex sugars to floculate.
Diacetyl, appearing as Butter or butterscotch in aroma/flavor is acceptable at lower levels.
Diacetyl, appearing as Butter or butterscotch in aroma/flavor unlike in some beers is unacceptable and considered as a technical flaw.
Increased carbonation may make diacetyl more noticeable in cider.
Judges need to keep in mind that increased carbonation may make diacetyl less noticeable in cider.
Diacetyl is sometimes a product of bacterial infection, and is known to occur during malolactic fermentation.
Diacetyl is a product of fermentation, and often can be cleaned up by malolactic fermentation.
Ethyl Acetate may be appearing as nail polish remover and a component of volatile acidity.
Solvent may be appearing as nail polish remover and a component of volatile acidity.
Ethyl Acetate (volatile acidity) is never appropriate at higher levels.
Ethyl Acetate (volatile acidity) is never appropriate in ciders and is technical fault.
Ethyl Acetate at low levels vague indistinct fruitiness, as such, can be quite welcome or pleasant.
Ethyl Acetate often becoming similar to pear drops at moderate levels, as such, can be quite welcome or pleasant.
Ethyl Acetate often becoming similar to pear drops at moderate levels, as such, always considered as a flaw in perries.
Ethyl Acetate is an intermediate byproduct of normal alcoholic fermentation that should normally be cleaned up by the yeast later.
Ethyl Acetate is an intermediate byproduct of normal alcoholic fermentation that normally doesn't clean up naturally.
Ethyl Acetate could be created during an infection by Zymomonas bacteria.
Ethyl Acetate could be cleaned up during malo-lactic fermentation by Zymomonas bacteria.
Ethyl Acetate can also be formed from an esterification reaction between Acetic Acid and Ethanol.
Ethyl Acetate can also be formed from an esterification reaction between Malic Acid and Methanol.
Low levels of Ethyl Acetate can be quite pleasant, adding complexity in the form of delicate, indistinct fruitiness or slight pear character.
Higher levels of Ethyl Acetate give a solvent character or reminiscent of nail polish remover, which are a serious fault.
Even lower levels of Ethyl Acetate give a solvent character or reminiscent of nail polish remover, which are a serious fault.
Ethyl Acetate appears as nail polish remover and a component of Volatile Acidity (VA).
Solvent appears as nail polish remover and a component of Volatile Acidity (VA).
Farmyard character appears as manure-like (cow or pig) or barnyard (horse stall on a warm day).
Mousey character appears as manure-like (cow or pig) or barnyard (horse stall on a warm day).
Farmyard appears in aroma as manure or barnyard, sometimes described as horse blanket, leathery, or old horse.
Mousey appears in aroma as manure or barnyard, sometimes described as horse blanket, leathery, or old horse.
Farmyard appears in flavor of burlap or leather, earthy or manure-like.
Mousey appears in flavor of burlap or leather, earthy or manure-like.
Farmyard character is appropriate at low levels in English and French ciders experiencing MLF, but should not dominate.
Farmyard character is a fermentation byproduct, never appropriate at any levels and is considered a serious flaw.
Farmyard character is at high levels generally indicative of an undesirable bacterial or Brettanomyces infection.
Farmyard character is always indicative of an undesirable bacterial or Brettanomyces infection.
Hints of old horse may be OK, while an overt pig manure or sewage character is not.
Hints of old pig barn may be OK, while an overt horse blanket is not.
Significant amounts of barnyard character without spicy or smoky phenols generally indicates a Brettanomyces infection.
Significant amounts of barnyard character with spicy and smoky phenols generally indicates a Brettanomyces infection and a major flaw.
Keeping cider at low pH (below 3.8) and low temperature (below 60F) can inhibit both Brett and lactic acid bacteria.
White spots or a papery white film on the surface of conditioning vessels or bottles indicate Film Yeast contamination.
White spots or a papery white film on the surface of conditioning vessels or bottles indicate excessive amount of Sulfur Dioxide in a cider.
If film-yeast left unchecked it can create strong solventy ethyl acetate aroma, as well as breaking down alcohol and making the cider seem dull, insipid or musty.
If malo-lactic bacteria left unchecked it can create strong solventy ethyl acetate aroma, as well as breaking down alcohol and making the cider seem dull, insipid or musty.
Film-yeast generally is not appropriate, but may not be noticeable or may even be considered positive until at moderate levels.
Film-yeast is always not appropriate, and well noticeable at very low levels; always considered negative and a serious flaw.
Film-yeast generally is product of infection by wild yeasts, typically Mycoderma vini or Candida mycoderma.
Film-yeast generally is product of certain wine yeasts native to Southern Europe regions including the wild yeasts, typically Saccharomyces florentinus or Torulaspora delbrueckii.
Floral character in ciders is very often appropriate; depends on the source and the style.
Floral character in ciders usually is not appropriate; depends on the source and the style (if spices or herbs were added).
Some level of fruitiness is appropriate in all cider both for aroma and flavor.
Some level of fruitiness is appropriate only in cider with other fruit or perries.
In the case of cider that has experienced MLF, fruitiness may be nothing like the original apple character.
Malolactic fermentation tends to reduce overt fruitiness in ciders.
Malolactic fermentation tends to increase overt fruitiness in ciders.
Mere presence of esters is not a flaw, however fermentation aromatics should not dominate a cider.
Presence of esters is a flaw, since fermentation aromatics bring cider out of balance.
Geranium leaf character is created from interaction of Lactic Acid Bacteria with sorbate.
Geranium leaf character is created from interaction of Malic Acid with sulfates.
Geranium Taint appears as musky aroma and flavor reminiscent of geranium leaves; some liken it to kerosene.
Geranium Taint appears as musky aroma and flavor reminiscent of cannabis leaves; some liken it to diesel.
Geranium Taint is never appropriate for any styles.
Geranium Taint at lower levels is very pleasant and adds complexity to a finished beverage.
Geranium Taint/Leaf character is formed, there is no fix.
Geranium Taint/Leaf character can be fixed by aging or splash-racking the cider.
Hydrogen Sulfide appears as rotten egg, hot springs, sometimes sewage, in flavor and especially aroma.
Sulfur Dioxide appears as rotten egg, hot springs, sometimes sewage, in flavor and especially aroma.
Which fault/characteristics in ciders sometimes also called "Rhino Farts"?
Hydrogen Sulfide are inappropriate at high levels.
Hydrogen Sulfide are inappropriate in ciders and always a flaw.
As hydrogen sulfide is a natural part of fermentation and quite volatile, low levels would not be considered a major fault and judges should give it a chance to dissipate.
Even though hydrogen sulfide is a natural part of fermentation, presence of it should  be considered a minor fault and judges should still penalize the cider.
Sometimes after the aeration of a few swirls and taking 30 seconds to describe the Appearance, a judge may find the previous slight sulfide no longer noticeable.
Sometimes after the aeration of a few swirls and taking 30 seconds to describe the Appearance, a judge may find the previous sulfide reduced, but it never goes away completely.
Insufficient nutrients during fermentation is the most well-known source of an H2S character; in such cases simply choosing a less needy strain can reduce sulfide.

Lower temperature or insufficient yeast pitch is the most well-known source of an hydrogen sulfide (H2S) character; in such cases simply doubling the yeast pitch size and fermenting at higher temperature can reduce sulfide.
A low temperature, slow fermentation will require generally fewer nutrients than a fast, higher temperature fermentation, thus would produce less hydrogen sulfide.
A low temperature, slow fermentation will require generally more nutrients than a fast, higher temperature fermentation, thus would produce more hydrogen sulfide.
“Splashy racking” and treatment with copper are often recommended for hydrogen sulfide.
“Splashy racking” and treatment with copper are often recommended for sulfide dioxide.
Copper sulfate treatment can treat sulfide at the expense of other aromatics.
Copper sulfate treatment can treat sulfide and enhance fruity esters and apple aroma.
A copper penny (pre-1982 in the USA) added to the cider results in reduced sulfide aroma, however copper cannot treat all sulfur compounds such as disulfides or DMS.
A copper penny (pre-1982 in the USA) added to the cider (also known as “Penny Trick”) results in reduced including all sulfur compounds such as disulfides or DMS.
Excessive nutrient additives, corroded equipment, or equipment not properly cleaned and rinsed may present as metallic.
Excessive nutrient additives, corroded equipment, or equipment not properly cleaned and rinsed may present as solvent.
Excessive nutrient additives, corroded equipment, or equipment not properly cleaned and rinsed may present as metallic.
Excessive nutrient additives, corroded equipment, or equipment not properly cleaned and rinsed may present as solvent.
Moldy/Musty appears as stale, cellar-like, earthy, compost-like, wet soil after rain, wet dog, wet cardboard and old rag flavors and aromas. Never appropriate.

Moldy/Musty appears as stale, cellar-like, earthy, compost-like, wet soil after rain, wet dog, wet cardboard and old rag flavors and aromas. At lower levels maybe add extra character and appropriate for English or Scrumpy ciders.
Mousey characteristics appear distinctive musky flavor reminiscent of a rodent’s den.
Moldy/Musty characteristics appear distinctive musky flavor reminiscent of a rodent’s den.
Mousey characteristics appear distinctive musky flavor reminiscent of a rodent’s den.
Moldy/Musty characteristics appear distinctive musky flavor reminiscent of a rodent’s den.
Mousey flavor reminiscent of rodent cage, sometimes perceived as wet rodent fur, bread-like, (unbuttered) popcorn or Cheerio.
Barnyard flavor reminiscent of rodent cage, sometimes perceived as wet rodent fur, bread-like, (unbuttered) popcorn or Cheerio.
Ability to detect mouse varies significantly by person as well as the pH of the judge’s palate at that given moment.
It is very easy to detect mouse character specially when the pH of the judge's palate is low (specially after consuming tart and acidic ciders).
Judges should expect to perceive mouse only in flavor and there should be no associated aroma.
Judges should expect to perceive mouse only in armona and there should be no associated flavor.
Judges should expect to detect mouse character both in armona and flavor.
Mousey is caused  by an infection by certain species of Brettanomyces or Lactobacillus, whether intended or not.
Mousey is caused  by an infection by certain species of Candida mycoderma or Zymomonas bacteria, whether intended or not.
Mousiness is controlled with adequate sulfite levels for cider pH, particularly during conditioning, to prevent secondary fermentation.
Once mousiness is present there is no known fix for it.
Once mousiness is present it may take up to a year to age it out (at low temperature with low pH).
Ropy character has a sheen in visual appearance, as an unpleasant viscous character proceeding to a slimy character.
Mousey character has a sheen in visual appearance, as an unpleasant viscous character proceeding to a slimy character.
Oily/Ropy caused by infection by certain species of Lactobacillus.
Oily/Ropy caused mostly by improper usage of certain ale yeast.
Oily/Ropy can be controlled with proper pH and sulfite levels for juice pH, particularly during conditioning.
Oily/Ropy can be controlled with reducing the head space in a carboy and preventing the exposure to oxygen particularly during conditioning.
Ropiness needs to be treated in advance of bottling as there is no treatment for it later.
Ropiness should be treated in advance of bottling , otherwise extended aging/conditioning would be required.
Oxidation in cider appears as stale, dull aroma and flavor, sometimes perceived as sherry, caramel, leather, nutty, or bruised or dried fruit.
Cloyingness/Sweetness in cider appears as stale, dull aroma and flavor, sometimes perceived as sherry, caramel, leather, nutty, or bruised or dried fruit.
Oxidation can possibly appear with an increased bitterness level or with color changes, typically in the golden brown to orange range.
Geranimum taint can possibly appear with an increased bitterness level or with color changes, typically in the golden brown to orange range.
“Papery” is sometimes mentioned with beer and mead but if experienced with cider it could be due to off flavors related to a filter pad or moldy cork.
“Papery” is sometimes mentioned with beer and mead has the same nature in cider.
Appropriateness of oxidation in cider depends on style, level, and specific character of oxidation.
Oxidation in cider usually is a flaw and only acceptable at very low levels in New England and Ice Cider.
Use of antioxidants such as ascorbic acid and sulfites can limit negative oxidation effects.
Use of antioxidants such as ascorbic acid and sulfites can limit negative oxidation effects in ciders, but not in perries.
Micro-oxidation of a cider in the bottle is a huge component of flavor development.
Micro-oxidation of a cider in the bottle must be prevented by any means, which is usually done by usage of oxygen absorbing caps.
Phenolic appears in ciders as a large group of organic chemicals often having plastic, medicinal or tar-like aromatics.
Geranium Taint appears in ciders as a large group of organic chemicals often having plastic, medicinal or tar-like aromatics.
Phenolics appear in ciders as a large group of organic chemicals often having plastic, medicinal or tar-like aromatics.
Geranium Taint appears in ciders as a large group of organic chemicals often having plastic, medicinal or tar-like aromatics.
Phenolics perceived as spicy, herbal, smoky, plastic, band-Aid, mouthwash, medicinal, clove, pepper or vanilla aroma and flavor.
Phenolics perceived as acrid, burning match aroma and flavor, may present as somewhat soapy in flavor.
Phenolics are appropriate in ciders that have undergone MLF but must not dominate.
Phenolics are inappropriate in ciders except for those that produced in Belgium.
Phenolics are appropriate in some ciders but considered to be a flaw in all perries.
Phenolics should add interest, not completely dominate the cider.
A judge’s review of phenolics will largely focus on whether said characters are appropriate and their levels/intensity in balance with other cider characteristics in the style being judged.
A judge’s review of phenolics will largely focus on causes and control measurements since in major cases it is a flaw and can affect both aroma, flavor and even appearance.
Solvent is perceived as hot burning on palate, harsh finish and aftertaste.
Solvent is perceived as hot, spicy, vinous aromas and flavors, warming or burning mouthfeel and aftertaste, sometimes an increased impression of sweetness.
Headaches are commonly noted soon after consumption of some fusels.
Stomach cramps are commonly noted soon after consumption of some fusels.
Solvent or fusel alcohols and ethyl acetate is never appropriate for any cider.
Solvent character at very low levels may add complexity to some traditional styles and only appropriate in English or Spanish ciders.
Solvent character includes many causes including high fermentation temperatures, stressed fermentation with insufficient nitrogen, etc.
Solvent character includes many causes including very low yeast counts, high gravity, lack of one of several trace vitamins, or from wild yeast infection, etc.
Solvent character includes many causes including usage of wrong yeasts (Belgian strains), certain types of apples (Yellow Mill, Kings Black, Derby), over-crushing the apples, etc.
Spicy/Smoky character perceived in Aromas and flavors as spicy, gingery, peppery, clove-like, smoky, bacon or ham.
Vegetal character perceived in Aromas and flavors as spicy, gingery, peppery, clove-like, smoky, bacon or ham.
Spicy/Smoky character is appropriate in cider that has undergone MLF, but must not dominate.
Spicy/Smoky character is appropriate only in ciders with spice and herbs or in category of specialty ciders and perries.
Very often spicy/smoky character present in English or French style cider or C2 Specialty Ciders with an English, French, or Spanish base, but out of place and generally a flaw in other styles.
If present spicy/smoky character is acceptable only in English style or C2 Specialty Ciders with an English base, but out of place and generally a flaw in other styles.
Very minor spiciness from wood-aging would not be a flaw, however it must remain low unless entered and declared in the appropriate C2 Specialty Cider and Perry style.
Spiciness from wood-aging would be considered as a flaw, since it is would be caused by bacterial infection from the barrel.
Which of the following would not be a part of common sulfur compounds in cider?
Which of the following sulfur compounds would be perceived as rotten egg or sewager?
Which of the following sulfur compounds would be perceived as cooked corn or vegetal?
Which of the following sulfur compounds would be perceived as garbage or stagnant water in a clogged drain?
Which of the following sulfur compounds would give burnt match character and at high level may irritate the nose?
Which of the following sulfur compounds is most similar to cabbage or rubber?
Which of the following sulfur compounds is familiar additive to natural gas that gives a strong odor many identify as skunk, onion, or garlic?
Sulfur is a major part of fermentation and its mere presence isn’t necessarily a fault.
Sulfur is a product of poorly controlled fermentation (low nutrients, wild yeast, unstable temperature) and its presence is considered as a technical fault.
As judges it isn’t really important that you identify which exact sulfur compounds are present in a competition entry, since they are often changing even while in the bottle.

As judges it is very important that you identify which exact sulfur compounds are present in a competition entry, to provide the most constructive and accurate feedback with ways to fix the issue in the future.
Judges must inform the entrant what flavor/aroma is there, at what level, and how it affects the other flavors/aromas, balance, and overall experience, rather then identifying exact sulfur compound.
Sulfur Dioxide is sulfites compound added for stability or as an antioxidant.
Sulfur Dioxide is a product of fermentation and its mere presence isn’t necessarily a fault.
Sulfur Dioxide is preceived as acrid, burning match aroma and flavor, may present as somewhat soapy in flavor.
Sulfur Dioxide is preceived as rotten egg, sewage, garbage or stagnant water in a clogged drain.
High levels of sulfur dioxide are inappropriate.
Sulfur Dioxide is inappropriate at all levels.
Low levels of sulfur dioxide could be acceptable.
The amount of sulfite necessary to protect a batch of cider is highly dependent on pH.
The amount of sulfite necessary to protect a batch of cider is highly dependent on its form (liquid vs crystalized).
Decreasing pH may allow a lower, less noticeable amount of sulfites to be used.
Increasing pH may allow a lower, less noticeable amount of sulfites to be used.
Decreasing pH may allow a lower, less noticeable amount of sulfites to be used.
Increasing pH may allow a lower, less noticeable amount of sulfites to be used.
If a cider is excessively sweet generally this means it was back-sweetened excessively for the amount of amount of alcohol, acid, and tannin in the cider.
If a cider is excessively sweet generally this means it was fermented without nutrients with lager yeast forcing the yeast to flocculate before achieving full attenuation.
Occasionally excessive sweetness could occur if a batch was keeved or fermentation otherwise stopped prematurely.
Tannic (polyphenolic) characteristics percieved as astringent, mouth-puckering mouthfeel, sometimes with lingering harshness, grape skin or “boiled tea” character, increased bitterness, drier finish.
Geranium Taint characteristics percieved as astringent, mouth-puckering mouthfeel, sometimes with lingering harshness, grape skin or “boiled tea” character, increased bitterness, drier finish.
Tannins (Polyphenolics) include added ingredient characters sometimes described as “woody,” or “oaky”.
Tannins (Polyphenolics) include added ingredient characters sometimes described as “metallic,” or “coppery”.
Tannins are appropriate at some level in every style.
Tannins are appropriate only in English and French ciders.
A matter of balance, high levels of acid may demand lower tannins or vice versa.
A matter of balance, high levels of acid may demand higher tannins or vice versa.
Over time tannins tend to polymerize into larger forms, becoming less bitter and more astringent.
Over time tannins tend to polymerize into larger forms, becoming more bitter and less astringent.
An excessively tannic beverage may improve with age.
An excessively tannic beverage may get more bitter with age.
Powdered wine tannin may present difficulty in getting it evenly blended into a cider.
Vegetal characteristics are never appropriate at high levels.
Vegetal characteristics are never appropriate in ciders.
The various characters that might be called Herbaceous (herbal/vegetal) that are present in many apples and not necessarily flaws.
The various characters that might be called Herbaceous (herbal/vegetal) that are present in many apples and always a flaw.
Mild amounts of yeastyness can be pleasant, but will generally interfere with a “clean” impression.
Strong yeasty flavor and aroma with excessive carbonation may indicate primary fermentation was not finished and has continued in the bottle.

Cider or perry is almost always made using a blend of different varieties of fruit which are often classified as Sweet, Sharp, Bittersweet, or Bittersharp based on their levels of acidity and tannins.
Cider or perry is almost always made using a blend of different varieties of fruit which are often classified as Table, Heirloom, Eating, or Cooking based on their levels of acidity and tannins.
Perry pears are much harder then table pears, making them almost impossible to eat raw.
Table pears are much harder then perry pears, making them almost impossible to eat raw.

Dessert pears are similar to dessert apples in their acid, sugar and tannin levels, but they usually have a very soft texture when ripe, making it very difficult to press them properly using a standard cider press.

Dessert pears are similar to dessert apples in their acid, sugar and tannin levels, but they usually have a very hard texture when ripe, making it very easy to press them properly using a standard cider press.
Pasteurization is undesirable and unnecessary for juice intended for cider (AKA “hard cider”) or perry.
Pasteurization is desirable and necessary for juice intended for cider (AKA “hard cider”) or perry.
Heat or flash pasteurization tends to “set” pectin in apple or fruit juice, making it impossible to remove without filtration.
Heat or flash pasteurization tends to separates pectins in apple or fruit juice, making it easy to remove.
Sorbates are used to inhibit the growth of mold, yeast and fungi and are added to most canned or refrigerated bottled fruit juices.
Diammonium Phosphate are used to inhibit the growth of mold, yeast and fungi and are added to most canned or refrigerated bottled fruit juices.
When making cider it is better if you can obtain ultraviolet or otherwise “cold” pasteurized juice instead of heat or flash pasteurized.
When making cider it is better if you can obtain heat or flash pasteurized juice instead of ultraviolet or otherwise “cold” pasteurized.
Sweating is the process of storing harvested apples or pears to allow the starches within to convert to sugar.
Macerating is the process of storing harvested apples or pears to allow the starches within to convert to sugar.
The flavor of the fruit also develops during sweating phase as some water evaporates, which will also increase sugar concentration and lower the juice yield.
The flavor of the fruit also develops during maceration phase as some water evaporates, which will also increase sugar concentration and lower the juice yield.
Yeast Assimilable Nitrogen (YAN) tends to decrease during sweating, which can help if one is planning to perform a Keeve or other nutrient-limited fermentation.
Yeast Assimilable Nitrogen (YAN) tends to decrease during sweating, which can help if one is planning to perform a Maceration or other nutrient-limited fermentation.
Some juice will be extracted during the milling process. If maceration is to be performed, the pomace should be left on this juice rather than being separated.
Some juice will be extracted during the milling process. If sweating is to be performed, the pomace should be left on this juice rather than being separated.
Some juice will be extracted during the milling process. If maceration is to be performed, the pomace should be separated from the juice.
Maceration is a period of allowing a milled pomace to sit before pressing.
Sweating is a period of allowing a milled pomace to sit before pressing.
Keeving is a period of allowing a milled pomace to sit before pressing.
Maceration of an apple pomace will develop color through oxidation of tannins as well as develop flavor.
Keeving of an apple pomace will develop color through oxidation of tannins as well as develop flavor.
While post-fermentation oxygen contact is to be avoided, oxidation during maceration is highly desirable.
Just like during post-fermentation oxygen contact is to be avoided, oxidation during maceration should be avoided.
Enzymes in the acid will start breaking down pectic during maceration, improving the yield of juice during pressing.
Enzymes in the acid will start breaking down pectic during sweating, improving the yield of juice during pressing.
The pear tannin molecules tend to be quite large compared to apple tannins, and prone to polymerization.
The pear tannin molecules tend to be quite small compared to apple tannins, and protected from polymerization.
Depending on the pear variety, allowing a pear pomace an extended maceration before pressing may reduce haze problems as well as develop flavor.
Depending on the pear variety, allowing a pears an extended sweating before milling and pressing may reduce haze problems as well as develop flavor.
Tannin levels in perry pears can be very high and may need to be reduced for enjoyment and even palatability of the finished product.
Sweetness levels in perry pears usually is high and may need to be reduced for enjoyment and even palatability of the finished product.
Tannin precipitation is favored by high acidity, low temperature, and presence of oxygen.
Tannin precipitation is favored by low acidity, high temperature, and lack of oxidation.
Increasing alcohol concentration and presence of sulfur dioxide retard precipitation of tannins.
Increasing alcohol concentration and presence of sulfur dioxide emphasize precipitation of tannins.
Juice pressed in a zero oxygen environment tends to be extremely tart and near water-white, with one-note acidity and little other flavor.
Juice pressed in a zero oxygen environment tends to be extremely tannic with one-note bitterness and little other flavor.
The longer the juice is exposed to air the more it will take on a brown color and characteristics associated with oxidation.
The longer the juice is exposed to air the more it will take on a tartness reducing the sweetness due to oxidation.
Acidity, tannins, and sugar level of the juice are all influenced through blending.
Acidity, tannins, and sugar level of the juice are all influenced through milling process.
Pears tend to have slightly higher gravity than many apples and most do not need chaptalization.
Pears tend to have lower gravity than many apples and most will need chaptalization.
It is generally desirable for ciders and perries to be within a pH of 3.3 and 3.8 at the beginning of fermentation.
It is generally desirable for ciders and perries to be within a pH of 3.8 and 4.8 at the beginning of fermentation.
Any cider or perry with pH above a 4.0 could be at risk of contamination.
Any cider or perry with pH above a 3.3 could be at risk of contamination.
Any cider or perry with pH below a 3.1 end up too acidic and tasting too sharp.
Any cider or perry with pH below a 3.8 end up too acidic and tasting too sharp.
What is the primary reason for acid adjustments prior to fermentation?
options: Adjusting the balance in the cider
Protecting the fermenting beverage from contamination

question: TA (Titratable Acidity), unlike pH is a more accurate measurement of how acidic a cider will be perceived on the palate.
pH, unlike TA (Titratable Acidity) is a more accurate measurement of how acidic a cider will be perceived on the palate.
VA (Volatile Acidity), unlike pH is a more accurate measurement of how acidic a cider will be perceived on the palate.
The lack of nutrients (especially nitrogen) starves the yeast, forcing them to ferment very slowly, over a period of weeks or months.
The lack of nutrients (especially nitrogen) starves the yeast, forcing them to ferment very fast, over a period of few days.
The slow fermentation helps preserve delicate aromatic compounds in the juice and preserves higher levels of sugar.
The fast fermentation with adequate addition of nutrients helps preserve delicate aromatic compounds in the juice and preserves higher levels of sugar.
Pear juice typically has lower nutrient levels than apple, and may need additional nutrients to avoid sluggish fermentation.
Apple juice typically has lower nutrient levels than pear, and may need additional nutrients to avoid sluggish fermentation.
Keeving or Défécation is a variant on low nutrient fermentation.
Keeving or Défécation is a variant on combining sweating and macerating techniques to produce a French style cider.
Keeving consists of removing nitrogen from the juice by “complexing” it with pectins, so the combined nitrogen and pectin mix falls out of solution and can be removed.
Keeving consists of adding nitrogen to the juice by “complexing” it with tannins, so the combined nitrogen and tannins mix provide special nutrients for the yeast.
Wild or Spontaneous Fermentation is the traditional method of making cider.
Wild or Spontaneous Fermentation is very rare method of making cider and only done to produce Spanish Ciders.
Fermentation of apple juice does not generally affect cider tannin however pear juice tannins may reduce during fermentation of Perry.
Fermentation of pear juice does not generally affect perry tannin however apple juice tannins may reduce during fermentation of cider.
Flavors will change during fermentation – cider that tastes like raw unfermented apple juice is generally a flaw.
Even though flavors may also change during fermentation – cider still should have flavors of fresh apples.
The process of adding sugar, syrup or similar fermentable additives to fruit juice to make a stronger fermented beverage is called chaptalization.
The process of adding sugar, syrup or similar fermentable additives to fruit juice to make a stronger fermented beverage is called champanization.

Sometimes used when experiencing dry versions of styles like New World Cider or Applewine.

question: Which statement is not true about the term “young”?
options: Fruit characters may be indistinct or muddled, or in the case of recent backsweetening with juice seem raw and unfermented.
The lingering taste on the palate, usually noticed in the back of the throat.
This descriptor can come off as presumptive, however there is nothing wrong with telling an entrant that the cider presents as young.
Alcohol may seem higher than it truly is, especially with bigger styles

question: Which statement is not true about the term “young”?
options: The often unstated companion phrase is that the cider may improve with time.
Generally unbalanced, rough cider that has not yet matured.
This descriptor can come off as presumptive, however there is nothing wrong with telling an entrant that the cider presents as young.
Alcohol may seem higher than it truly is, especially with bigger styles.

question: Malolactic Fermentation (MLF) is the conversion of one molecule of malic acid (C4H6O5) into one molecule of lactic acid (C3H6O3) plus one molecule of carbon dioxide (CO2)
Malolactic Fermentation (MLF) is the conversion of one molecule of simple sugar into malic and lactic acid plus one molecule of carbon dioxide (CO2)
Which one is not true about Malolactic Fermentation (MLF)?
options: MLF alters the balance of the cider by reducing acidity.
MLF is a side effect of keeving process.
MLF may present significant flavor and aroma changes.

question: Malolactic Fermentation (MLF) slightly increases carbonation and alters the balance of the cider by reducing acidity.
Malolactic Fermentation (MLF) significantly increases carbonation and alters the balance of the cider by increasing acidity.
MLF is not performed by the beer or wine yeasts pitched to make cider or by wild yeasts already present in the fruit, but rather by Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB).
MLF is performed by the beer yeasts pitched to cider after fermentation is complete.
The three main classes of Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) that perform MLF are Pediococcus, Oenococcus, and Lactobacillus.
The three main classes of Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) that perform MLF are Debaryomyces, Brettanomyces, and Torulaspora delbrueckii.
Which of the four classes of Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) does not perform MLF?
Lactobacillus has several species common in cider and is what creates the phenolics associated with the BJCP English Cider style and to a lesser extent French Cider.
Brettanomyces has several species common in cider and is what creates the phenolics associated with the BJCP English Cider style and to a lesser extent French Cider.
Lactic acid bacteria are inhibited by high alcohol, low pH, low temperature, lack of nutrients, high relevant acid concentrations, and presence of bound and especially free sulfites.
Lactic acid bacteria are inhibited by low alcohol, high pH, high temperature, over-usage of nutrients, and presence of bound and especially free sulfites.
Temperature of 60 °F (15 °C) is low enough to keep most strains from starting, though it will often continue at this temperature if it has already begun.
Temperature of 65 °F (17 °C) is high enough to keep most strains from starting.
Lactic Acid Bacteria like the 60 – 75 °F (15 – 24 °C) temperature range, with some variation between individual strains.
Lactic Acid Bacteria like the 50 – 60 °F (10 – 15 °C) temperature range, with some slight variation between individual strains.
Generally pH below 3.2 will keep MLF from beginning, and many strains are at least somewhat inhibited below 3.5.
Generally pH below 4.0 will keep MLF from beginning, and many strains are at least somewhat inhibited below 4.2.
Generally pH above 4.0 will keep MLF from beginning, and many strains are at least somewhat inhibited above 3.5.
The following Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) is known to produce smoky phenolic character in a cider.
Oenococcus generally works at lower pH than Lactobacillus and Pediococcus, reducing acidity without added phenolic characters.
Oenococcus generally works at higher pH than Lactobacillus and Pediococcus, reducing acidity and adding phenolic characters.
Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) can also metabolize sugars as yeast do, creating things like acetic acid that cidermakers want to avoid in the finished product.
Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB) does not metabolize sugars as yeast do, creating things like linoleic acid.
Extremely high levels of malic acid can create an environment that inhibits Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB), while high levels of lactic acid may kill LAB.
Extremely high levels of lactic acid can create an environment that inhibits Lactic Acid Bacteria (LAB), while high levels of malic acid may kill LAB.
Complete reduction of malic acid (during MLF) will reduce the acidity by half if no other acids are present.
Complete reduction of malic acid (during MLF) will reduce the acidity by 15% if no other acids are present.
Cidermakers strive to keep pH low enough (<3.8) to help protect the cider from microbial contamination and may monitor the increase.
Cider with lactic acid often seems smoother, less metallic, and more approachable then with malic acid.
Cider with malic acid often seems smoother, less metallic, and more approachable then with lactic acid.
Cider that has experienced MLF would have lower amounts of overt apple and perhaps a more nuanced fruit character.
Pronounced barnyard funk aroma without the spicy and smoky phenolics generally indicates a Brett infection.
Pronounced barnyard funk aroma without the spicy and smoky phenolics generally indicates a Oenococcus oeni infection.
Spicy, smoky, restrained barnyard aromas/flavors are the result of the LAB breaking down phenolic acids in the apple juice.
Spicy, smoky, restrained barnyard aromas/flavors are the result of the LAB breaking down tannins in the apple cider.
Spicy, smoky, restrained barnyard phenolics are NOT associated with the Oenococcus oeni strains that winemakers are pitching to finish their red wines.
Spicy, smoky, restrained barnyard phenolics are associated with the Oenococcus oeni strains that winemakers are pitching to finish their red wines.
Dessert apples can have high levels of phenolic acids and very low tannin levels, i.e., one does not need a tannic cider to be able to perform phenolic MLF.
Diacetyl is acceptable in cider as long as it complements the finished product, especially New World Cider.
A small amount of butter isn’t a reason to disqualify a cider from medal contention, but diacetyl should never be a dominant character.
A small amount of butter can be a reason to disqualify a cider from medal contention, even if diacetyl is not a dominant character.
A small amount of butter can be a reason to disqualify a cider from medal contention, even if diacetyl is not a dominant character.
Despite the increase in pH during MLF may leave the cider prone to bacterial contamination, the process can still promote a stable cider.
In performing malolactic fermentation LAB are removing other nutrients from the cider, thus, those nutrients are not available for other spoilage microbes to consume.
In performing malolactic fermentation LAB are adding other nutrients to the cider, thus, those nutrients would be available for other spoilage microbes to consume.
With appreciable residual sugar, fairly low acid, and low alcohol content, French Cider can be among the least stable ciders.
With appreciable residual sugar, fairly low acid, and low alcohol content, French Cider can be among the most stable ciders.
The keeving practice is more common in traditional styles, most specifically French Cider.
The keeving practice is more common in traditional styles, most specifically German Cider or Apfelvein.
At its core keeving is about removal of nutrients from apple or pear juice.
At its core keeving is about doubling nutrients in apple or pear juice natural way.
In Keeving, the goal of the removal of nutrients is to starve the yeast before fermentation would normally end in dryness.
In Keeving, the goal of adding nutrients is to over-exhaust the yeast before fermentation would normally end in dryness.
Keeved cider differs from other methods primarily due to two processes except for:
options: Natural pH increase by producing a lactic acid

question: Removal of nutrients from apple/pear juice during keeving is done enzymatically with Pectin Methylesterase (PME).
Removal of nutrients from apple/pear juice during keeving is done enzymatically with Pectic Enzyme (PE).
Pectin Methylesterase (PME) is not the same as the Pectic Enzyme (pectinase) often added to cider to promote clarity.
Pectin Methylesterase (PME) is very similar to the Pectic Enzyme (pectinase) often added to cider to promote clarity.
Use of dessert fruit naturally high in nutrients is unlikely to result in a successful keeve.
Use of dessert fruit naturally high in nutrients is most likely to result in a successful keeve.
Pectin Methylesterase (PME) works better at higher pH, may struggle to successfully keeve an extremely high acid, low pH must.
Pectin Methylesterase (PME) works better at lower pH, may struggle to successfully keeve a low acid, high pH must.
Keeving is perfectly suited for the bittersweet apples heavily used in French-style ciders.
In addition to PME, a successful keeving requires the presence of Calcium.
In addition to PME, a successful keeving requires the presence of Magnesium.
In addition to PME, a successful keeving requires the presence of Magnesium.
